docs.lead_paragraph: The Humana Insurance Company unit of Humana Inc. announced a health plan for individuals called HumanaOne yesterday, representing the company's first large-scale venture into the individual health insurance market. Humana said HumanaOne is meant to appeal to individuals and families not insured by their employer, including self-employed entrepreneurs, students, early retirees and those between jobs. Humana is offering the plan in Illinois and Ohio.

headline.main: HUMANA OFFERS HEALTH INSURANCE FOR INDIVIDUALS

docs.abstract: Humana Insurance Co unit of Humana Inc announces health plan for individuals called HumanaOne, representing company's first large-scale venture into individual health insurance market; plan is meant to appeal to individuals and families not insured by employer (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Warning that a surge in costs threatens to swamp the employer-subsidized health system within a decade, a new study by a group representing large employers says that $390 billion a year is being wasted on outmoded and inefficient medical procedures. The costs pile up from several sources, according to the study, which is being published today. Among them is the overuse of surgical procedures, tests and medicines; the failure to routinely provide flu and pneumonia vaccines or appropriate tests and follow-up medicines for heart and diabetes patients; and inadequate screening for breast cancer, depression and certain venereal diseases.

headline.main: Study Finds Inefficiency in Health Care

docs.abstract: Juran Institute study of large employers, warning that surge in costs threatens to swamp employer-subsidized health system within decade, says $390 billion per year is being wasted on outmoded and inefficient medical procedures; says costs are coming from overuse of surgical procedures, tests and medicines, failure to routinely provide flu and pneumonia vaccines or appropriate tests and follow-up medicines for heart and diabetes patients, and inadequate screening for breast cancer, depression and certain venereal diseases; Midwest Business Group on Health president Jim Mortimer says poor quality in health care costs typical employer estimated $1,700 to $2,000 for each covered employee each year; study says federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid projects national spending on health care will soar to $2.82 trillion in 2011, almost double last year's $1.42 trillion; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Joe Torre's daily routine includes updating reporters on injuries affecting his players. Torre, the Yankees' manager, may discuss a pitcher's shoulder tendinitis or an outfielder's chronic knee trouble. It has been standard operating procedure in baseball and other professional sports for decades. But under a federal law that all health-care providers, including the Yankees, will have to comply with by next April, Torre and other sports officials who talk about injuries may be prevented from disclosing a player's medical information without consent.

headline.main: Law May Forbid Leagues to Say If Player Is Hurt

docs.abstract: Legislation preventing healthcare providers, like Major League Baseball teams, from disclosing personal information about health of beneficiaries to media might keep teams from discussing player injuries in future, despite regularity with which such disclosure is practiced now (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WellPoint Health Networks Inc., one of California's biggest health insurers, raised its 2002 earnings forecast to $4.30 a share from $4. The revision is based primarily on strong medical membership growth in important regions and assumes the continuation of current economic conditions, the company said. Wellpoint said 2002 membership would grow by nearly 10 percent, more than the 5 percent to 7 percent growth the company had forecast earlier.

headline.main: WELLPOINT HEALTH NETWORKS RAISES EARNINGS FORECAST

docs.lead_paragraph: Responding to a severe shortage of nurses, the City University of New York, the city's largest producer of nursing graduates, plans to sharply expand its training programs, adding 30 full-time nursing professors and scheduling more classes on nights and weekends. Last year, CUNY graduates accounted for about 36 percent of the newly licensed registered nurses in the New York metropolitan area, the university said. The 12 CUNY campuses that offer nursing programs had nearly 1,000 graduates last year, including both associate's and bachelor's degree graduates.

headline.main: CUNY to Add Teachers to Nurse Program

docs.lead_paragraph: Mariano Rivera aggravated a strained right groin muscle Saturday against the San Francisco Giants and will probably be placed on the 15-day disabled list today. It is the second time in three weeks that a groin injury has forced Rivera to be sidelined, so the Yankees want to correct the problem before it can become chronic. ''They want to take the precaution of doing everything now to make sure that everything is perfect,'' Rivera said.

headline.main: Reinjured Rivera Heads for Disabled List

docs.abstract: New York Yankees Notebook discusses pitcher Mariano Rivera's second groin injury of season, which will likely sideline him for 15 days; Andy Pettitte, Roger Clemens and David Wells will all pitch against New York Mets in upcoming interleague series; rookie outfielder Juan Rivera is sidelined with fractured kneecap; Yankees will no longer provide medical information about player injuries to media; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: No nation on earth has ever tried as hard, and failed as utterly, in its efforts not to become rich as America has. From the start our great leaders have tried to steer us away from the pitfalls of great wealth. Thomas Jefferson campaigned against manufacturing and commerce, fearing we would become a nation of ''gamblers'' and ''jugglers'' who spent their lives performing ''tricks with paper.'' John Adams was convinced that big money would lead to our downfall: ''Human nature, in no form of it, could ever bear Prosperity.'' Almost all of our great thinkers and writers have joined the cause. The Transcendentalists railed against materialism. ''Simplicity, simplicity, simplicity'' was Henry David Thoreau's advice. Mark Twain lambasted the values of the Gilded Age. Thorstein Veblen ridiculed self-indulgent consumerism. Left-wing beatniks like Allen Ginsberg condemned the money-mad ''Moloch whose mind is pure machinery,'' while conservative stuffed shirts like Henry Cabot Lodge warned that ''the adoration of money is an ever-present peril.''

headline.main: Why the U.S. Will Always Be Rich

docs.abstract: David Brooks article holds that money in America has been transformed into an environment of abundance, which makes Americans keenly aware of possibilities within their grasp and energizes them to realize those possibilities; says this accounts both for America's wealth and fact that Americans have not been corrupted by it; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Regarding ''What Malpractice Insurance Crisis? (Soapbox, May 26): Our out-of-control malpractice system is forcing many of my colleagues in high-risk specialties, especially obstetrics, to restrict their practice and limit certain procedures. Others are retiring early or leaving the state. Many lawyers sue everyone within miles, hoping the insurance company will settle the case against a non-negligent physician for less money than the cost of litigation. Although physicians win close to 80 percent of cases that go to trial, they may still be labeled a high risk and suffer adverse consequences. On the few occasions when juries do find for the plaintiff, they are often as generous as a dozen Regis Philbins.

headline.main: Debating Lawyers' Role In Malpractice Insurance

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Regarding ''Practicing Without a Net'' (cover, May 2): As a trial lawyer with 20 years' experience representing patients in New Jersey, I have yet to see the frivolous malpractice case that yields a multimillion-dollar settle or verdict. Any patient who has brought a malpractice case in the state knows that MIIX and the other insurance companies defend every case aggressively and have superior access to expert witnesses, the most important element of a malpractice case.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Is Your Health Insurance Hurting Your Credit?'' (May 12) noted that New York's ''prompt pay'' law, requiring health plans to pay undisputed claims within 45 days, serves as an important protection for consumers. Not mentioned was the state's ''hold harmless'' law, which protects consumers against billing by providers in certain instances.
docs.abstract: Joseph R Baker III letter on May 12 article notes New York law bars health care providers who participate in HMO's from billing members because of late payment by HMO
